The Science & Story Behind It

This fern is a miniature marvel of natural engineering:

  • Azolla forms a symbiosis with the cyanobacterium Anabaena azollae, which lives in cavities within its leaves. The bacterium converts atmospheric nitrogen into ammonia, a form of nitrogen the plant can use, a process known as nitrogen fixation.
  • For centuries, it has been used in rice paddies in Southeast Asia as a natural fertilizer, famously referred to as “green manure.”
  • The Azolla fern event is a paleontological hypothesis that suggests a massive bloom of Azolla in the Arctic Ocean 49 million years ago played a key role in transitioning the Earth from a “greenhouse” to an “icehouse” climate by drawing down atmospheric CO₂.

In short, Azolla ‘Nitro-Fern Nano’ is a symbiotic nutrient engine, a living link to ancient planetary processes that you can harness to create a more fertile and sustainable closed-loop garden.
